com.nokia.dempsy.router
Interface RoutingStrategy

public interface RoutingStrategy

A RoutingStrategy is responsible for determining how to find the appropriate Node within a given cluster given a MessageKey. It has both an RoutingStrategy.Inbound side and an RoutingStrategy.Outbound side that work together using the MpCluster to do the bookkeeping necessary.

A simple example would be: a non-elastic, fixed-width cluster RoutingStrategy that simply selects the Node to send a message to based on the mod ('%' operator) of the hash of a message's key with the number of nodes in the cluster.

In this example the RoutingStrategy.Inbound strategy, which would be instantiated in each node, would be implemented to register the its current Node with the MpCluster. The RoutingStrategy.Outbound side would use the registered information to select the appropriate Node.

As mentioned, RoutingStrategy implementations need to be balanced. The RoutingStrategy.Inbound can safely assume that the RoutingStrategy.Outbound created from the same strategy was responsible for setting up the cluster.

RoutingStrategy.Inbound and RoutingStrategy.Outbound need to be thought of in terms of the stages of a pipeline in a Dempsy application. E.g.: 

 
 Adaptor --> inbound1|Stage1|outbound2 --> inbound2|Stage2|outbound3 ...

Notice that outbound2 and inbound2 require coordination and are therefore defined in the ApplicationDefinition using a single RoutingStrategy as part of the ClusterDefinition that defines Stage2

As an example, the DefaultRoutingStrategy's Inbound and Outbound coordinate through the cluster. The Inbound side negotiates for slot ownership and those slots contain enough information for the Outbound side

Implementations must be able to handle multi-threaded access.
